Speaker.P: Grants from the European Social Fund are available in respect of the costs of training disabled persons for open employment. The grants are made to statutory and non-statutory bodies providing training facilities rather than directly to individual disabled persons.

A number of agencies providing training services in Limerick are in receipt of assistance from the fund. These include the Mid-Western Health Board, the Rehabilitation Institute, the Brothers of Charity and RETOS Shannon (via the Mid-Western Health Board).

The amounts granted from the European Social Fund specifically to the National Rehabilitation Board are set out below. As final payments are not normally made for some time after the year to which they relate, the amounts stated for 1984 and 1985 have not yet been paid in full.

MainHeading.P: The reduction in ESF funding for the NRB in 1985 was due to a stricter interpretation by the European Commision of the guidelines relating to the operation of the fund.

Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Social Welfare (Mr. B. Desmond)

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - European Community Farm Accountancy Committee.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Noonan (Limerick West) Mr. Noonan (Limerick West)
Speaker.P: (Limerick West) asked the Minister for Agriculture if he will confirm that his Department has responsibility for appointing the Irish representative on the Brussels Committee of the Farm Accountancy Data Network; and if so, if he will outline (1) who entrusted this task to his Department; (2) when his Department was given this task; (3) the present members of this committee; (4) if Ireland is alone in not having any farmer or non-Civil Service representation on this committee; (5) if any of the farming organisations have ever been consulted regarding the composition of this committee; and (6) if Dáil Éireann has ever been notified of appointments to this committee.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Agriculture (Mr. Deasy) Austin Deasy
Speaker.P: The EC Committee on the Farm Accountancy Data Network is one of a large number of official committees involved in the day-to-day operation of different aspects of the Common Agricultural Policy. These committees are chaired by the Commission and consist of representatives of the member states. They do not include any producer or trade interests. The servicing of the FADN Committee is part of the on-going work of my Department and the actual representation at meetings of the committee depends on the agenda and on the general work situation.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Agriculture (Mr. Deasy) Austin Deasy

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Agriculture (Mr. Deasy) Austin Deasy

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Noonan (Limerick West) Mr. Noonan (Limerick West)
Speaker.P: (Limerick West) asked the Minister for Agriculture if he will confirm that those farmers who availed of the non-marketing of milk scheme have a contractual right to resume milk production; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Noonan (Limerick West) Mr. Noonan (Limerick West)
Speaker.P: (Limerick West) asked the Minister for Agriculture if his Department is obliged to secure a milk quota for farmers who participated in the non-marketing of milk scheme.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Noonan (Limerick West) Mr. Noonan (Limerick West)
Speaker.P: (Limerick West) asked the Minister for Agriculture if it will be possible for him to secure additional quota allotments from Brussels to cater for farmers who availed of the non-marketing of milk scheme; and if he agrees that it should not be necessary for individual farmers to initiate expensive legal procedures to achieve their rights; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Agriculture (Mr. Deasy) Austin Deasy
Speaker.P: I propose to take Questions Nos. 153, 154 and 155 together. There are no special provisions in the Community regulations for producers who participated in the non-marketing schemes. Thus those whose non-marketing period expired before or during 1983 are entitled to a quota based on their actual 1983 deliveries if they had re-commenced deliveries by that time. Those whose non-marketing period expired after 1983 are in the same position as a producer entering milk production for the first time and as such are dependent on a temporary quota allocation from any flexi-milk available in their cooperative-dairies, after the priority categories have been dealt with.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Collins Mr. G. Collins
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Agriculture if he will provide details of all projects in County Limerick which have been granted aid from the FEOGA section of the Common Agricultural Policy; furthermore whether any FEOGA grants which might have been sanctioned at EC level for projects in County Limerick have not been taken up; and, if so, if he can provide a full explanation as to the reason why this is the case.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Agriculture (Mr. Deasy) Austin Deasy
Speaker.P: I assume that the Deputy is referring to the FEOGA scheme of grants for projects relating to the processing and marketing of agricultural and fish products under Regulation (EEC) No. 355/77 and under its predecessor, Regulation (EEC) No. 17/64 which provided for grant-aiding water supply schemes also. Details of projects awarded FEOGA aid under these regulations are set out in the following table. Of the total of £568,296 awarded under Regulation (EEC) No. 17/64, £147,190 has been renounced or underclaimed due to non-implementation or non-completion of the relevant projects. The corresponding amount renounced or underclaimed under Regulation (EEC) No. 355/77 is £315,472. Any amounts renounced or underclaimed by Irish concerns are immediately reallocated to other Irish projects. A total of £1,487,873 has been paid so far under the two regulations leaving a balance of £665,444 still to be claimed. While this situation is not entirely satisfactory, it is to be borne in mind that £405,936 of this balance relates to projects approved only within the last 18 months. Approved applicants are allowed four to five years to complete their projects. It is the policy of my Department and the IDA to encourage firms to submit their claims as rapidly as possible and the take-up of funds under the scheme has improved significantly in recent years.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Agriculture (Mr. Deasy) Austin Deasy

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. Hussey) Gemma Hussey
Speaker.P: In the case of the first school referred to by the Deputy, my Department has requested the school authorities to lodge the local contribution towards the cost of the project. When this is done the contract will be placed and work can commence without delay. The duration of the contract is expected to be about nine months.

In the case of the second school, it is expected that the preparation of the contract documents will be completed in about two weeks' time. The question of the invitation of tenders will then be considered and a decision conveyed to the school authorities at the earliest possible date. It is not possible to say at this stage when building works in this case will commence or be completed. It is not my Department's practice to disclose the financial details of individual school projects, as these are confidential matters between my Department and the school authorities.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Yates Mr. Yates
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Labour the amount of the redundancy entitlement of a person (details supplied) in County Wexford and when it will be paid.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Labour (Mr. Quinn) Ruairí Quinn
Speaker.P: My Department has received no claim in respect of a redundancy lump sum payment to the employee in question. It has been ascertained, however, from the employer that the employee was recently paid a redundancy lump sum of £453.92, the equivalent of four weeks' normal pay. According to the employer, the person concerned had six years' service — all under the age of 41.

The Redundancy Payments Acts, 1967 to 1984, provide for a redundancy lump sum payment to be calculated at the rate of a half week's pay for each year of service between the years of 16 and 41 plus the equivalent of one week's normal pay. On the basis of the information received from the employer, the redundancy lump sum in this case appears to have been correctly calculated.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Aylward Mr. Aylward
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Labour if he will arrange to have any outstanding moneys due to a company (details supplied) in County Tipperary paid in respect of redundancies where the employees have already been paid their redundancy moneys.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Labour (Mr. Quinn) Ruairí Quinn
Speaker.P: The company concerned was paid the full rebate due from the redundancy and employers' insolvency fund on 16 December 1985 in respect of a redundancy lump sum payment made to one former employee. No other claim has been received from this employer.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Community Youth Training Programmes.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Collins Mr. G. Collins
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Labour if he will provide details of the number of AnCO operated community youth training programmes which have been completed in County Limerick; and the duration and number of jobs created by such programmes since Ireland became a member of the European Community; and if he will also provide a global figure for the value of European Social Fund aid provided for the operation of these programmes.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Labour (Mr. Quinn) Ruairí Quinn
Speaker.P: Since the commencement of the community youth training programme (CYTP in 1976 the total number of completed CYTP projects in the Limerick area is 43. The average duration of CYTP projects is approximately six months. The total number trained on the CYTP projects run in County Limerick from 1976 to date is 3,218. Since 1976 the total expenditure on CYTP's in County Limerick is £4.8 million of which £2.6 million constituted European Social Fund Aid.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Collins Mr. G. Collins
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Labour if he will give details relating to the number of young people in County Limerick who have applied for and who have been accepted for EC backed CERT courses; the number of CERT trainees from County Limerick who have actually completed CERT courses and have found employment subsequently in the hotel and catering business and if he will also provide information relating to the level of European Social Fund aid provided for CERT trainees.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Labour (Mr. Quinn) Ruairí Quinn
Speaker.P: Comprehensive information in the detail sought by the Deputy is available for 1985 only. In 1985, applications for places on formal training programmes were received from 330 persons with addresses in County Limerick. Of these 50 persons actually commenced training. A total of 19 persons from Limerick completed formal training courses in 1985 and all of these persons were placed in employment. In addition in 1985, courses for unemployed persons were run by CERT in two temporary training centres in County Limerick, at Kilfinane and Limerick city. These courses provided training for 82 unemployed persons.

In 1984, a temporary centre was run in Limerick city catering for 40 unemployed persons and in 1983 a temporary centre in Shannon, County Clare, catered for 35 persons with addresses in the County Limerick area.

The average rate of placement in employment for these courses run at temporary centres was 83 per cent. The total cost of all the programmes mentioned above is estimated at £271,000, of which 55 per cent was contributed by the European Social Fund.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Collins Mr. G. Collins
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Labour if he can confirm the estimate that by the end of 1985 the training centres for travelling people in Ireland will accommodate approximately 500 people and that AnCO involvement is funded by the Youth Employment Agency and the European Social Fund; and the number of these places that are being filled by travelling people in County Limerick.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Labour (Mr. Quinn) Ruairí Quinn
Speaker.P: By the end of 1985 the training capacity of traveller training centres will be 569. AnCO funds for these workshops are provided from the youth employment levy and the European Social Fund. The capacity of traveller training centres in County Limerick is 24 persons.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - County Limerick AnCO Statistics.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Collins Mr. G. Collins
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Labour if he will provide details of the number of people, including young people under the age of 25, from County Limerick who have availed of AnCO courses since Ireland's entry into the EC, and the number of County Limerick participants in AnCO courses who have been successful in finding permanent employment as a result of their AnCO training.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Labour (Mr. Quinn) Ruairí Quinn
Speaker.P: Precise details of the persons trained from County Limerick are not readily available. However, AnCO trained 12,305 persons including young people under 25 years of age in the period 1973 until end November 1985 on its courses organised by its Limerick training centre which in the main serves County Limerick and parts of Counties Clare and Tipperary. In addition, AnCO has organised external training courses in County Limerick. Readily available information on these dates only from 1982 and indicates that 2,028 persons were trained on these courses to date.

The numbers trained above include those trained on AnCO's specific employable skills/mainline courses and others trained on courses providing basic skills e.g. community workshops, traveller workshops and community youth training programme projects. The average placement rate in respect of the specific employable skills/mainline courses run by the Limerick training centre since 1973 is 72 per cent. The average placement of such external training courses in the county since 1982 is 65 per cent.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Collins Mr. G. Collins
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Labour if he will provide an indication of the role of the Government's social employment scheme since it began its operations with particular reference to job creation in County Limerick; and the extent to which aid from the EC is being used to support the social employment scheme.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Labour (Mr. Quinn) Ruairí Quinn
Speaker.P: The social employment scheme which was launched in February, 1985 is aimed at helping the large number of productive and energetic people over 25 who have been unemployed for an extended period to make their contributions to social and community development. Since the first projects under the scheme commenced operation in May 1985 over 5,400 positions have been filled in 1,373 projects under SES.

The response from among the ranks of the long term unemployed, at whom the scheme is aimed, has been heartening. The large numbers who have indicated their wish to participate in the scheme and make a contribution to environmental, cultural and social development in their communities, has ensured its success. In each of the last three months over 1,000 persons have taken up employment under the scheme.

It is not possible at present to give details of employment under the scheme in County Limerick as statistics are compiled on a regional basis only. However, in the mid-west region of the National Manpower Service which encompasses Counties Limerick, Clare and Tipperary (North Riding), 407 persons are employed on 110 projects at present. The social employment scheme qualifies for assistance from the European Social Fund at a rate of £13.20 per participant per week.
